The SDR approach is based on the reformulation of the BQO problem as a semidefinite program (SDP), which can be efficiently solved using existing SDP solvers. The proposed method is able to handle large-scale BQO problems with thousands of variables and constraints. The paper also provides applications of the proposed method in various domains, including machine learning, computer vision, and operations research. Experimental results demonstrate the effectiveness and efficiency of the proposed method compared to existing approaches. Overall, this paper contributes to the field of large-scale BQO optimization and provides practical solutions for real-world applications.

The Riemann hypothesis is one of the most famous unsolved problems in mathematics. In this paper, we explore various equivalences of the Riemann hypothesis and their connections to other important conjectures and inequalities. We begin by discussing the Robin inequality, which is a result related to the Riemann hypothesis. We then introduce Lagarias criterion, which provides a necessary and sufficient condition for the Riemann hypothesis to hold. Finally, we examine the connections between the Riemann hypothesis and other conjectures, such as the Goldbach conjecture and the twin prime conjecture. Through our analysis, we aim to shed light on the deep connections between these conjectures and provide further insights into the Riemann hypothesis.

The abstract of the academic paper titled "Chiral phase transition in a planar four-Fermi model in a tilted magnetic field" summarizes the key findings and contributions of the study. The paper investigates the chiral phase transition in a planar four-Fermi model in the presence of a tilted magnetic field. The authors use a mean-field approximation and perform a systematic analysis of the phase diagram. They find that the chiral transition is significantly affected by the tilt of the magnetic field, leading to the emergence of additional critical points. The study provides novel insights into the behavior of the chiral phase transition in the presence of external magnetic fields, which has implications for understanding the physics of condensed matter systems and high-energy physics phenomena.

This paper presents a modeling and simulation study on the effects of cyclic loading on the formation of articular cartilage lesions. The study aims to understand the underlying mechanisms of lesion formation and provide insights into potential preventive measures. A finite element model of the knee joint is developed, incorporating the mechanical properties of articular cartilage and the loading conditions experienced during cyclic activities. The model is validated using experimental data and then used to simulate the effects of different loading parameters on lesion formation. The results show that cyclic loading can lead to the development of cartilage lesions, with higher loading magnitudes and frequencies resulting in more severe lesions. The study also investigates the role of cartilage thickness and composition in lesion formation. Overall, the findings contribute to a better understanding of the biomechanics of articular cartilage and provide a basis for future research on preventive strategies for cartilage lesions.

In this academic paper, we explore the concept of B\"acklund transformations and present some new perspectives on this topic. B\"acklund transformations are a powerful mathematical tool used to find solutions to differential equations. We provide an overview of the history and development of B\"acklund transformations, highlighting some important advancements in the field. Additionally, we introduce some new approaches and techniques for studying B\"acklund transformations, including the use of symmetry methods and Lie algebras. Through numerical examples and theoretical analysis, we demonstrate the effectiveness and applicability of these new perspectives. This paper aims to contribute to the existing knowledge and understanding of B\"acklund transformations, providing researchers with valuable insights and tools for further research in this field.

This paper presents a novel approach for mammogram edge detection using hybrid soft computing methods. Mammogram edge detection is a crucial step in the early detection of breast cancer. Traditional edge detection methods often fail to accurately detect edges in mammograms due to the complex and noisy nature of the images. In this study, a hybrid approach combining fuzzy logic and genetic algorithms is proposed to overcome these limitations. The fuzzy logic system is used to model the uncertainty and imprecision in mammogram images, while the genetic algorithm is employed to optimize the parameters of the fuzzy logic system. Experimental results on a dataset of mammogram images demonstrate that the proposed hybrid approach outperforms traditional edge detection methods in terms of accuracy and robustness. The findings of this study have important implications for improving the early detection and diagnosis of breast cancer.

Image segmentation is a fundamental task in computer vision that involves partitioning an image into meaningful regions. In this paper, we propose a novel approach to image segmentation based on iterative inference from conditional score estimation. Our method leverages the power of deep neural networks to estimate the conditional score of each pixel given its context. We then iteratively update the segmentation mask by maximizing the conditional score of each pixel. Experimental results on various benchmark datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach, achieving state-of-the-art performance in terms of both accuracy and efficiency. Furthermore, we provide an in-depth analysis of the proposed method, shedding light on its strengths and limitations. Overall, our work contributes to the field of image segmentation by introducing a new approach that combines the strengths of deep learning and iterative inference.

In recent years, deep learning-based methods, such as convolutional neural networks (CNNs) and transformer models, have demonstrated remarkable performance in various computer vision tasks, including 3D medical image segmentation. However, CNNs struggle to capture long-range dependencies, while transformers lack efficient parameter use and prohibitively high memory consumption. In this paper, we propose a novel approach called CoTr, which efficiently bridges CNNs and transformers for 3D medical image segmentation. Specifically, we introduce a hybrid architecture that combines the strengths of both models, leveraging CNNs for local feature extraction and transformers for long-range context understanding. Our proposed method achieves competitive results on benchmark datasets for 3D medical image segmentation, demonstrating its potential for accurate and efficient segmentation in clinical applications. Furthermore, we conduct extensive experiments and ablation studies to validate the effectiveness of our approach, highlighting the advantages of CoTr over existing methods. Overall, our work contributes to advancing the field of 3D medical image segmentation by integrating CNNs and transformers in an efficient and effective manner.

This paper presents a novel approach for the segmentation of medical imaging data using Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs). The segmentation of medical images plays a crucial role in various clinical applications, such as tumor detection, organ localization, and treatment planning. However, the manual segmentation process is time-consuming and prone to inter-observer variability. To address these challenges, we propose a CNN-based segmentation method that can automatically learn the features and classify the pixels of medical images. The proposed approach consists of three main steps: data preprocessing, CNN training, and post-processing. In the data preprocessing step, we apply various preprocessing techniques to enhance the quality of the medical images. Then, we train a CNN model using a large dataset of annotated medical images. The trained CNN model can accurately classify the pixels of medical images into different anatomical structures or lesions. Finally, we employ post-processing techniques, such as morphological operations and conditional random fields, to refine the segmentation results and improve the overall accuracy. We evaluate the proposed approach on a publicly available dataset of brain MRI images, and the experimental results demonstrate that our method achieves competitive performance compared to state-of-the-art methods. The proposed CNN-based segmentation method has the potential to improve the efficiency and accuracy of medical image segmentation and facilitate various clinical applications.

The Deep Inelastic Scattering (DIS) process is an important tool for studying the structure of particles in high-energy physics. The process involves the exchange of virtual particles, which can be described by the Dokshitzer-Gribov-Lipatov-Altarelli-Parisi (DGLAP) integro-differential equation. In this paper, we present an analytical solution to the DGLAP equation in a simple toy-model with a fixed gauge coupling. We derive explicit expressions for the parton distribution functions and investigate their dependence on the evolution variable. Our results provide insight into the behavior of the DGLAP equation and offer a potential framework for understanding the dynamics of DIS processes in more complex systems.

This paper presents a novel method for label fusion in cardiac magnetic resonance (MR) images using neural networks. Label fusion is an important step in medical image analysis, where multiple atlases are registered to a target image and their labels are combined to generate a final segmentation. The proposed method utilizes a convolutional neural network (CNN) to learn the relationship between the atlases and the target image, and then uses this learned information to fuse the labels. The CNN is trained using a large dataset of cardiac MR images and their corresponding atlases. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed method outperforms existing label fusion techniques in terms of accuracy and robustness. The proposed method has the potential to improve the accuracy and efficiency of cardiac MR image analysis, which can have significant implications in clinical practice.

In this paper, we investigate the relationship between supersymmetry and the eigensurface topology of the spherical quantum pendulum. We first introduce the concept of supersymmetry and its application in quantum mechanics. We then analyze the eigensurface topology of the spherical quantum pendulum and show that it exhibits a rich structure with multiple connected components. We further demonstrate that the eigensurface topology is closely related to the presence of supersymmetry in the system. Specifically, we find that the number of connected components of the eigensurface is determined by the number of supersymmetric partners of the system. Our results provide new insights into the connection between supersymmetry and the topology of quantum systems, and may have implications for the study of other physical systems.

The paper investigates the $L^2$ well-posedness of boundary value problems for parabolic systems with measurable coefficients. The authors analyze the existence and uniqueness of weak solutions in the $L^2$ framework and provide criteria for the regularity of these solutions. They introduce a suitable variational formulation and prove the existence of solutions using the Galerkin approximation method. The authors also establish estimates for the solutions and prove uniqueness by combining the characteristics of parabolic systems and the regularity properties of the coefficients. Their results provide a foundation for the analysis of boundary value problems for parabolic systems with measurable coefficients and contribute to the theoretical understanding of these systems.

This paper examines the structural limitations of learning in Massive Open Online Courses (MOOCs) by focusing on two main factors: communication vulnerability and information diffusion. The study analyzes the communication patterns and diffusion of information in two popular MOOCs to understand how these factors may limit the effectiveness of learning. The findings suggest that the lack of meaningful interactions and the limited reach of information within the crowd hinder the learning experience in MOOCs. The paper concludes by discussing the implications of these limitations and suggesting potential strategies to improve learning outcomes in MOOCs.

This paper presents a theoretical and experimental study of non-diffracting chirped Bessel waves in optical antiguides. The authors investigate the propagation characteristics of these waves in antiguides with different refractive index profiles. The results show that the chirped Bessel waves can maintain their non-diffracting properties over a certain distance, which is determined by the chirp rate and the refractive index profile. The authors also demonstrate the generation and manipulation of these waves using a spatial light modulator. The findings of this study have potential applications in optical communication and imaging systems.

This paper focuses on the privacy concerns related to semantic image segmentation models. Semantic image segmentation is a widely used technique in computer vision that involves labeling each pixel in an image with its corresponding class. However, recent research has shown that these models can be vulnerable to membership inference attacks, where an adversary can determine if a specific image was used during the training of the model. This paper presents a comprehensive analysis of membership inference attacks in semantic image segmentation models and evaluates various defense mechanisms. The proposed defense mechanisms aim to mitigate privacy risks by either modifying the training process or adding noise to the inference outputs. Experimental results show that these defenses can significantly reduce the effectiveness of membership inference attacks while maintaining a reasonable level of segmentation performance. Overall, this work highlights the need for privacy-aware training techniques and defense strategies in semantic image segmentation models.

This paper proposes a novel approach for compressing 3D medical images and accurately segmenting them in cloud-based environments using machine vision techniques. The proposed method combines advanced compression algorithms with deep learning-based image segmentation models to achieve efficient transmission and accurate segmentation of medical images. Experimental results demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed approach in reducing the size of medical images while preserving important diagnostic information, as well as achieving high segmentation accuracy in a cloud-based environment. The proposed method has the potential to significantly improve the efficiency and accuracy of medical image analysis and transmission in cloud-based healthcare systems.

This paper presents a real-time prediction model for segmentation quality in image processing. The model takes into account various features of the image, including texture, color, and shape, and uses machine learning techniques to predict the quality of the segmentation. The model is trained on a large dataset of segmented images and evaluated on a separate test set. Experimental results show that the proposed model achieves high accuracy in predicting segmentation quality in real-time. This model can be useful in applications where accurate segmentation is critical, such as medical image analysis and object recognition.

In this paper, we explore the concept of s-increasing sequences of r-tuples and investigate the maximum length of such sequences. We define an s-increasing sequence of r-tuples as a sequence of r-tuples in which each subsequent r-tuple has at least one element that is greater than or equal to the corresponding element in the previous r-tuple, and the difference between the elements of each r-tuple is at least s. We provide a formula for calculating the maximum length of an s-increasing sequence of r-tuples and present a proof for this formula. Additionally, we discuss the application of this concept in various fields, such as combinatorics and optimization. Our findings contribute to a deeper understanding of the structure and properties of s-increasing sequences of r-tuples and provide a useful tool for analyzing and solving related problems in different domains.

In this paper, we investigate the existence and properties of static solutions for nonminimally coupled topological-defect boson stars. We consider a scalar field theory with a nonminimal coupling to gravity and study the effects of this coupling on the formation and stability of boson stars. We find that the nonminimal coupling can significantly affect the properties of the boson stars, including their mass, size, and stability. We also explore the parameter space of the theory and identify regions where stable boson star solutions exist. Our results provide new insights into the formation and properties of topological-defect boson stars in the presence of a nonminimal coupling to gravity.

This paper presents an analysis of Fisher information and the Cramr-Rao bound for nonlinear parameter estimation after compressed sensing. Compressed sensing is a technique used to efficiently acquire and reconstruct sparse signals. In this study, we consider the problem of estimating parameters in a nonlinear model from compressed measurements. We derive expressions for the Fisher information matrix and the Cramr-Rao bound for this scenario. We also investigate the impact of the measurement matrix and the sparsity level on the estimation performance. Our results show that the Fisher information and the Cramr-Rao bound depend on the measurement matrix and the sparsity level, and that the estimation performance can be improved by carefully designing the measurement matrix. These findings provide valuable insights for the design and analysis of compressed sensing systems for nonlinear parameter estimation.

This paper presents an accelerated stochastic alternating direction method of multipliers (ADMM) algorithm with variance reduction. The proposed algorithm leverages variance reduction techniques to reduce the variance of the stochastic gradient, thereby improving the convergence rate and efficiency of the ADMM algorithm. The algorithm is evaluated through extensive experiments on both synthetic and real-world datasets, and the results demonstrate that the accelerated stochastic ADMM with variance reduction outperforms existing methods in terms of convergence speed and final solution quality. These findings highlight the potential of variance reduction techniques in improving the efficiency of optimization algorithms like ADMM in solving large-scale optimization problems.

Computer stereo vision is a key technology for enabling autonomous driving systems to perceive and understand the surrounding environment. This paper presents a comprehensive review of the state-of-the-art techniques and algorithms used in computer stereo vision for autonomous driving. The paper discusses the fundamental principles of stereo vision, including camera calibration, disparity estimation, and depth map generation. It also explores various approaches for handling challenges such as occlusions, dynamic scenes, and low-texture regions. Additionally, the paper examines the integration of stereo vision with other perception sensors, such as LiDAR and radar, to enhance the robustness and accuracy of autonomous driving systems. The paper concludes with a discussion on the future directions and potential advancements in computer stereo vision for autonomous driving.

This paper presents a deep active learning framework called Suggestive Annotation for biomedical image segmentation. The framework aims to reduce the annotation effort required for training deep learning models by selecting the most informative samples for annotation. The authors propose a novel uncertainty-based sampling strategy that combines both aleatoric and epistemic uncertainties to identify the most uncertain regions in the images. These regions are then annotated by human experts, and the annotated data is used to fine-tune the deep learning model. The authors evaluate the framework on two publicly available biomedical image datasets and compare it with other active learning strategies. The results show that the Suggestive Annotation framework outperforms other strategies in terms of segmentation accuracy while requiring fewer annotations. The proposed framework has the potential to significantly reduce the annotation effort and improve the efficiency of biomedical image segmentation tasks.

This paper investigates the effects of imperfections in channel geometry on the development of turbulent flows. It focuses on transitional flows, which occur between laminar and fully turbulent flow regimes. The study uses Direct Numerical Simulation (DNS) to analyze the influence of small-scale geometrical variations on the flow characteristics. The results indicate that even subtle imperfections can have a significant impact on the transitional flow development, leading to increased turbulence and flow instabilities. The findings provide new insights into the behavior of transitional flows in practical applications, such as pipe networks and industrial processes, and highlight the importance of considering geometric imperfections in the design and analysis of fluid systems.

Medical image segmentation is an important task in clinical evaluation, which plays a crucial role in accurate diagnosis and treatment planning. However, automated algorithms for medical image segmentation often make mispredictions due to various factors such as noise, artifacts, and anatomical variations. In this paper, we propose an efficient and generic interactive segmentation framework to correct mispredictions during the clinical evaluation of medical images. The framework utilizes user interactions to refine the segmentation results obtained from automated algorithms. Specifically, the user provides feedback by correcting the mispredictions, which is then used to update the segmentation model. The proposed framework combines a deep learning-based segmentation algorithm with an interactive user interface to provide a user-friendly and efficient segmentation correction process. Experimental results on a diverse set of medical images demonstrate the effectiveness and efficiency of the proposed framework in correcting mispredictions and improving segmentation accuracy. The framework shows great potential for enhancing the clinical evaluation of medical images and improving patient care outcomes. Overall, our work presents a valuable contribution to the field of medical image segmentation by enabling efficient and accurate correction of mispredictions during clinical evaluation.

This paper proposes a semi-supervised learning approach for aggregated multilayer graphs. The approach utilizes diffuse interface methods and fast matrix vector products to effectively learn from partially labeled data. The method is capable of handling large-scale datasets and achieves competitive performance compared to existing techniques. Experimental results on real-world datasets demonstrate the effectiveness and efficiency of the proposed approach. Overall, this paper presents a novel and practical solution for semi-supervised learning on aggregated multilayer graphs.

This paper presents a novel approach towards unsupervised learning for instrument segmentation in robotic surgery using cycle-consistent adversarial networks (CycleGANs). Instrument segmentation is a crucial task in robotic surgery to enable surgical robots to autonomously identify and track surgical instruments during surgery. However, obtaining labeled training data for instrument segmentation is challenging and time-consuming. In this work, we propose an unsupervised learning framework that leverages CycleGANs to learn a mapping between real surgical images and synthetic images with instrument annotations. By training on this synthetic data, the model can then be applied to real surgical images for instrument segmentation. The proposed method is evaluated on a dataset of laparoscopic videos and achieves promising results, demonstrating the potential of unsupervised learning for instrument segmentation in robotic surgery. The proposed framework has the potential to greatly improve the efficiency and accuracy of instrument segmentation in robotic surgery, leading to improved surgical outcomes and patient safety.

In recent years, Vision Transformers (ViTs) have emerged as a powerful architecture for image classification tasks. However, there is limited understanding of the best practices for training ViTs, including the role of data, augmentation, and regularization. This paper aims to address this gap by conducting a comprehensive study on training ViTs. We propose a novel data augmentation technique specifically designed for ViTs, termed vision-augmented contrastive learning (VACL), which leverages both local and global augmentation. Additionally, we investigate the impact of various regularization techniques, such as dropout and weight decay, on the performance of ViTs. Through extensive experiments on benchmark datasets, we demonstrate the effectiveness of VACL in improving the performance of ViTs. Furthermore, we provide insights into the importance of data size, diversity, and regularization in training ViTs. Our findings contribute to the development of best practices for training ViTs, paving the way for improved performance in vision tasks.

This paper presents a novel approach for segmenting greenhouses on high-resolution optical satellite imagery using deep learning techniques. The proposed method utilizes a convolutional neural network (CNN) architecture to automatically learn and extract relevant features from the input images. The CNN is trained on a large dataset of labeled greenhouse images, enabling it to accurately classify pixels as either greenhouse or non-greenhouse. The performance of the proposed method is evaluated on a test dataset, and the results demonstrate its effectiveness in accurately segmenting greenhouses. The proposed approach offers a promising solution for automating the process of greenhouse segmentation, which can have various applications in agriculture, urban planning, and environmental monitoring.

This paper presents a deep learning-based approach for object saliency detection and image segmentation. Object saliency detection aims to identify the most visually significant regions in an image, while image segmentation involves assigning a label to each pixel to identify different objects. Deep learning models, particularly convolutional neural networks (CNNs), have shown promising results in various computer vision tasks. In this study, we propose a novel deep learning architecture that combines a CNN with a number of advanced techniques, including spatial pyramid pooling, dilation, and skip connections. We train and evaluate our model on benchmark datasets, demonstrating its superior performance compared to existing methods. Our approach not only achieves state-of-the-art results in object saliency detection but also provides accurate image segmentation results. Furthermore, we analyze the interpretability of our model and show that it effectively captures and highlights meaningful object boundaries. Overall, our work contributes to the field of computer vision by providing a powerful and interpretable deep learning framework for object saliency detection and image segmentation.

Semantic segmentation is a fundamental task in computer vision that aims to assign a semantic label to each pixel in an image. Existing methods typically rely on either image-level or semantic-level context to improve segmentation accuracy. However, these methods often fail to capture the full range of contextual information available. In this paper, we propose a novel framework called ISNet that integrates both image-level and semantic-level context for semantic segmentation. ISNet consists of two modules: an image-level context module and a semantic-level context module. The image-level context module captures global contextual information by aggregating features from multiple scales, while the semantic-level context module captures local contextual information by incorporating semantic information from neighboring pixels. Experimental results on benchmark datasets demonstrate that ISNet outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of segmentation accuracy. Furthermore, ablation studies show that the integration of image-level and semantic-level context is crucial for achieving superior performance. Overall, our proposed ISNet framework provides a comprehensive solution for semantic segmentation by effectively leveraging both image-level and semantic-level context.

Meta-analysis is a statistical technique used to combine findings from multiple studies in order to generate an overall estimate of a treatment effect. In this paper, we propose and investigate selection models with monotone weight functions for meta-analysis. These weight functions allow for a flexible modeling of the selection process that occurs when studies are included in the meta-analysis. We provide a detailed description of the selection models and discuss their properties and advantages over existing approaches. We also develop a generalized least squares estimator for the weight function parameters and propose a modified version of the Bland-Altman plot for assessing model adequacy. Finally, we apply the proposed selection models to real data sets and demonstrate their performance through simulation studies. Our results indicate that the selection models with monotone weight functions are a valuable tool for meta-analysis and can lead to more accurate and precise estimates of treatment effects.

This academic paper investigates the problem of uplink and downlink rate balancing in cooperating cellular networks. The study focuses on optimizing the allocation of resources between the uplink and downlink channels in order to maintain a balance and improve network performance. The authors propose a novel algorithm that dynamically adjusts the resource allocation based on the network conditions and user demands. Through simulations and experiments, they demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed algorithm in achieving rate balancing and enhancing overall network capacity. The findings of this research can contribute to the design and optimization of cellular networks, leading to improved user experiences and network efficiency.

In this paper, we consider the problem of approximately sampling elements with fixed rank in graded posets. Graded posets are partially ordered sets where each element is assigned a rank. We propose a new algorithm for sampling elements with fixed rank in graded posets, based on a technique called rejection sampling. Our algorithm takes advantage of the graded structure of the poset to efficiently sample elements with fixed rank, providing a provable approximation guarantee. We present theoretical results analyzing the performance of our algorithm, as well as empirical evaluations on synthetic and real-world datasets. Our experiments demonstrate that our algorithm outperforms existing methods in terms of both accuracy and efficiency. Overall, our work contributes to the field of sampling algorithms for graded posets, providing a practical and effective solution to the problem of approximately sampling elements with fixed rank.

This paper presents a novel approach for the automated design of deep learning methods for biomedical image segmentation. The traditional manual design of deep learning architectures can be time-consuming and requires expert knowledge. In this work, a genetic algorithm is proposed to automatically search for optimal network architectures and hyperparameters. The algorithm is applied to the task of segmenting biomedical images, specifically retinal images and histopathology images. The results demonstrate that the automated approach can achieve comparable performance to manually-designed networks while significantly reducing the human effort involved. Furthermore, the automated approach is shown to be robust across different datasets and can adapt to various segmentation tasks. Overall, this work shows promising potential in advancing the field of biomedical image segmentation by automating the design process of deep learning methods.

This paper investigates the properties of linear integral equations that are related to the six-vertex model with a disorder parameter. The authors analyze the behavior of the solutions to these equations and derive various properties such as the existence and uniqueness of solutions, as well as the behavior of the solutions as the disorder parameter approaches certain critical values. The results obtained in this study provide valuable insights into the behavior of the six-vertex model with disorder and contribute to the understanding of this important mathematical model.

Ridge regression is a popular method for handling collinearity issues in linear regression models. This paper provides lecture notes on ridge regression, covering topics such as the motivation behind ridge regression, the ridge regression formula, the bias-variance trade-off, the choice of the ridge parameter, and extensions of ridge regression. The lecture notes aim to provide a comprehensive understanding of ridge regression and its application in practice. The paper concludes with a discussion on the advantages and limitations of ridge regression, as well as potential areas for future research.

This paper presents a survey on machine learning techniques for auto labeling of video, audio, and text data. Auto labeling is the process of automatically assigning labels or tags to data without human intervention. The paper provides an overview of the different machine learning algorithms and approaches that have been used for auto labeling in the context of video, audio, and text data. It discusses the challenges and limitations of these techniques and provides insights into the current state of the field. The survey also highlights the potential applications and future directions for research in this area. Overall, this paper serves as a comprehensive resource for researchers and practitioners interested in auto labeling of video, audio, and text data using machine learning techniques.

The paper proposes a novel method for learning to segment images when the training data consists of misaligned and partial labels. Traditional segmentation methods rely on accurate and complete annotation, which is often challenging and time-consuming to obtain. In this paper, we introduce a new approach that leverages weakly supervised learning techniques to address the issue of misaligned and incomplete annotations. Specifically, we propose a dual task network that simultaneously learns to predict both the class labels and the alignment offsets. By jointly training these two tasks, our model is able to effectively overcome the challenges associated with misalignment and partial labeling. Experimental results on a number of benchmark datasets demonstrate that our proposed method outperforms existing approaches in terms of segmentation accuracy and robustness to label noise. Overall, our work contributes to the field of image segmentation by improving the reliability and efficiency of annotation in the presence of misaligned and partial labels.

IPatch is a remote adversarial patch that can be deployed on an image classification system to cause misclassification of specific target classes. It leverages the power of adversarial attacks by embedding a small perturbation into the image, which is imperceptible to the human eye but causes the classifier to misclassify the image. The patch is generated remotely and applied to the target image, making it an effective method for launching attacks against image classification systems. Experimental results show that IPatch achieves high attack success rates, even against state-of-the-art defense mechanisms. The findings highlight the vulnerability of image classifiers to remote adversarial attacks and the urgent need for robust defense strategies.

This paper introduces a novel approach for multimodal and semi-supervised image segmentation. The proposed method, called Disentangle, Align and Fuse (DAF), aims to improve the accuracy and robustness of image segmentation by leveraging multiple modalities and incorporating limited labeled data. DAF consists of three main steps: disentanglement, alignment, and fusion. First, the different modalities are disentangled to extract separate feature representations. Then, an alignment module is used to align the features across modalities. Finally, the aligned features are fused to create a comprehensive representation for segmentation. Experimental results on various datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of DAF in achieving state-of-the-art performance in multimodal and semi-supervised image segmentation tasks. This paper serves as a valuable contribution to the field of image segmentation, providing a new approach that addresses the challenges of multimodal and semi-supervised scenarios.

In this paper, we study the nesting statistics in the $O(n)$ loop model on random maps of arbitrary topologies. We consider a lattice model where loops of $n$ different colors are randomly placed on a two-dimensional lattice. We investigate the distribution of nested loops, which are loops that are completely contained within another loop. We derive exact expressions for the average number of nested loops and the average size of nested loops in the thermodynamic limit. We also analyze the scaling behavior of the nesting statistics as a function of the loop length and the lattice size. Our results provide insights into the behavior of the $O(n)$ loop model on random maps and can be applied to various physical systems, such as polymers and spin systems.

This paper explores the concept of crepant resolutions and their relationship to open strings in the context of string theory. Crepant resolutions are a mathematical tool used to resolve singularities in algebraic varieties, and they have been shown to have important implications in string theory. The paper presents a detailed analysis of the mathematical properties of crepant resolutions and their connection to open strings. The authors also discuss the physical implications of crepant resolutions in the context of string theory, including their role in understanding the behavior of D-branes and the emergence of gauge theories. The paper concludes with a discussion of future directions for research in this area.

This academic paper presents a novel approach to abdominal multi-organ segmentation using voxel-level Siamese representation learning. Traditional segmentation methods for abdominal organs often rely on manually designed features and lack generalization ability. The proposed method leverages the Siamese neural network architecture to learn discriminative representations directly from raw voxel data. The network is trained on pairs of abdominal CT scans, where one scan contains the target organ and the other does not. The learned representations are used to construct an affinity matrix, which is then transformed into a segmentation map using a graph-cut algorithm. The proposed method is evaluated on a publicly available dataset and achieves state-of-the-art results in segmenting multiple abdominal organs, including the liver, spleen, and kidneys. The experimental results demonstrate the effectiveness of voxel-level Siamese representation learning for abdominal multi-organ segmentation and highlight its potential for clinical applications.

In this paper, we present GENESIS-V2, a novel approach for inferring unordered object representations without the need for iterative refinement. Our method builds upon the original GENESIS framework, which uses a generative model to learn object representations from unlabelled data. However, GENESIS-V2 introduces several key improvements, including a new architecture that incorporates a self-attention mechanism and a novel training objective that encourages the model to learn more discriminative representations. We evaluate our approach on several benchmark datasets and demonstrate that GENESIS-V2 outperforms existing methods in terms of both accuracy and efficiency. Furthermore, we provide an in-depth analysis of the learned representations and show that they capture meaningful semantic information about the objects. Overall, our work contributes to the field of unsupervised learning by providing a more effective and efficient method for inferring unordered object representations.

This paper proposes a map-guided curriculum domain adaptation approach for semantic nighttime image segmentation. The authors introduce a novel uncertainty-aware evaluation metric to assess the performance of the segmentation model. The proposed method utilizes a map-guided curriculum learning strategy to gradually adapt the model to nighttime scenes. The uncertainty-aware evaluation metric takes into account the uncertainty of the model predictions, providing a more accurate assessment of the segmentation performance. Experimental results demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed approach in improving the segmentation accuracy for nighttime images. The map-guided curriculum domain adaptation and uncertainty-aware evaluation contribute to the advancement of semantic nighttime image segmentation techniques.

This paper investigates S-folds, a class of supersymmetric deformations of four-dimensional N=4 super Yang-Mills theories which break supersymmetry down to N=3. The authors provide a detailed analysis of the properties and characteristics of S-folds, including their moduli spaces and conformal invariance. The paper also explores the implications of S-folds for the AdS/CFT correspondence and holography, highlighting their potential significance for understanding the duality between gravity in five dimensions and superconformal field theories in four dimensions. Overall, this paper contributes to the theoretical understanding of N=3 superconformal field theories, providing new insights and avenues for further research in the field.

This paper presents effective results for Diophantine equations over finitely generated domains. The authors develop a general framework for solving Diophantine equations and provide algorithms for finding solutions. They also analyze the complexity of these algorithms and provide bounds on the size of the solutions. The effectiveness of the results is demonstrated through several examples and applications. Overall, this paper contributes to the understanding and practical implementation of solving Diophantine equations over finitely generated domains.

Template-Based Active Contours is a paper that proposes a new method for active contour detection in image analysis. The traditional active contour algorithm is based on gradient information, making it prone to noise and weak edges. This paper introduces a template-based approach that combines gradient and texture features to overcome these limitations. By utilizing a template matching step, the proposed method aligns the contour with the object boundary, leading to improved accuracy and robustness. Experimental results show that the template-based active contours outperform traditional methods in terms of accuracy and efficiency, making it a promising approach for various image analysis applications.

This paper presents a novel approach for segmenting two-dimensional structures using strided tensor networks. The proposed method leverages the hierarchical structure of tensor networks to efficiently capture local and global dependencies in the input data. The segmentation task is formulated as a binary classification problem, where each pixel is assigned a label indicating whether it belongs to the foreground or background. Experimental results on various benchmark datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed method in accurately segmenting two-dimensional structures, outperforming state-of-the-art methods in terms of both accuracy and computational efficiency. The proposed approach has the potential to be applied to a wide range of image segmentation tasks in various domains, including medical imaging and computer vision.

This paper investigates the sliding friction behavior of a power-law fluid in the hydrodynamic lubrication regime. The authors conducted experiments using a custom-built tribometer to measure the friction coefficient as a function of sliding velocity and applied load. The results show that the friction coefficient decreases with increasing sliding velocity and reaches a minimum value at a critical velocity. Additionally, the friction coefficient increases with increasing applied load. The authors propose a theoretical model based on the Reynolds equation and the power-law fluid rheology to explain the observed friction behavior. The model predicts the critical velocity and the friction coefficient as a function of sliding velocity and applied load, which are in good agreement with the experimental data. This study provides insights into the sliding friction behavior of power-law fluids in the hydrodynamic lubrication regime and can be useful for the design and optimization of lubrication systems.

This paper investigates the possibility of covert communication over classical-quantum channels. Covert communication refers to the transmission of information without being detected by an eavesdropper. The authors propose a protocol that utilizes the principles of quantum mechanics to achieve covert communication. They analyze the security of the protocol against various eavesdropping strategies and provide theoretical bounds on the achievable covert communication rates. The results show that covert communication is indeed possible over classical-quantum channels, although the achievable rates are limited by the inherent noise and imperfections in the channel. The findings of this study have implications for the design of secure communication systems and can contribute to the development of covert communication techniques in practical scenarios.

This paper presents a study of the magnetic properties of Co/Ti bilayer thin films using ferromagnetic resonance (FMR) spectroscopy. The Co/Ti bilayer thin films were prepared using magnetron sputtering technique and their magnetic properties were characterized using FMR measurements. The FMR spectra were analyzed to determine the magnetic anisotropy and damping parameters of the Co/Ti bilayer thin films. The results showed that the magnetic anisotropy of the Co/Ti bilayer thin films can be controlled by varying the thickness of the Ti layer. The damping parameter was found to be dependent on the Co layer thickness. These findings provide valuable insights into the magnetic properties of Co/Ti bilayer thin films and can be useful for the development of magnetic devices and spintronic applications.

SemSegLoss is a Python package that provides a collection of loss functions for semantic segmentation tasks. Semantic segmentation is a fundamental problem in computer vision, where the goal is to assign a class label to each pixel in an image. The choice of an appropriate loss function is crucial for training accurate and robust semantic segmentation models. This paper introduces SemSegLoss, a comprehensive package that includes a variety of loss functions commonly used in the field. The package is designed to be flexible and easy to use, allowing researchers and practitioners to experiment with different loss functions and select the most suitable one for their specific task. The paper provides a detailed description of the implemented loss functions, along with examples of their usage and performance evaluation on benchmark datasets. The SemSegLoss package is publicly available and can be easily integrated into existing deep learning frameworks, making it a valuable resource for the semantic segmentation community.

The Social Force Model (SFM) is a commonly used agent-based simulation model for pedestrian dynamics and evacuation scenarios. In this paper, we investigate the stationarity of the evacuation process within the SFM. We conduct experiments using different initial conditions and observe the dynamics of evacuees over time. We find that the evacuation process in the SFM is not stationary, as both individual and collective behaviors change throughout the process. This observation challenges the commonly assumed equilibrium in the SFM and suggests the need for dynamic and time-dependent modeling approaches when simulating evacuation scenarios.

In this paper, we present an overview of modern convex optimization techniques applied to medical image analysis. Convex optimization has emerged as a powerful tool in various fields, including medical image analysis, due to its ability to find global optima and its efficiency in solving large-scale optimization problems. We discuss the application of convex optimization to various tasks in medical image analysis such as image denoising, image registration, image segmentation, and image reconstruction. We also highlight several key algorithms and methods that have been developed for these tasks, including convex relaxation, non-convex relaxations, and distributed optimization. Finally, we provide a discussion on the challenges and future directions in the application of convex optimization to medical image analysis, including the incorporation of deep learning and the development of new optimization frameworks.

MBIS is a multivariate Bayesian image segmentation tool that allows for the effective analysis and segmentation of digital images. The segmentation process is performed using a Bayesian framework, which takes into account the statistical properties of the image data. The tool uses a Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) algorithm to estimate the posterior distribution of the segmentation parameters. This allows for uncertainty quantification in the segmentation results, which is beneficial for decision-making and subsequent image analysis tasks. The tool has been tested on a variety of image datasets and has demonstrated robustness and accuracy in segmenting complex images. Overall, MBIS provides a valuable tool for image segmentation that can be used in a wide range of applications, including medical imaging, remote sensing, and computer vision.

This paper focuses on studying the phenomenon of bubble formation from a submerged orifice. The authors conducted experiments using different orifice sizes, water heights, and flow rates to investigate the effects on bubble formation. The results showed that the size and shape of the orifice significantly influenced the bubble formation, with larger orifices resulting in larger bubbles and vice versa. Additionally, the water height and flow rate also played a role in bubble formation, with higher water heights and flow rates resulting in faster bubble formation. The authors also examined the fluid dynamics involved in bubble formation and proposed a mathematical model to describe the process. Overall, this study provides valuable insights into the formation of bubbles from submerged orifices and contributes to a better understanding of fluid dynamics in multiphase systems.

MixSearch is an academic paper that introduces a novel approach to searching for domain generalized medical image segmentation architectures. The paper addresses the challenge of developing models that can perform well across different medical imaging domains, which often have varying characteristics and features. The proposed approach, called MixSearch, combines the advantages of both neural architecture search (NAS) and transfer learning to optimize the performance of segmentation models across multiple domains. The authors demonstrate the effectiveness of MixSearch through extensive experiments and comparisons with existing methods. The results show that MixSearch achieves state-of-the-art performance in domain generalized medical image segmentation tasks, proving its potential for improving the accuracy and efficiency of medical image analysis in a variety of applications.

Brain tumor segmentation is a crucial task in medical imaging that aims to accurately delineate tumor regions, which is important for diagnosis, treatment planning, and monitoring. In this paper, we propose a novel one-pass multi-task network with cross-task guided attention for brain tumor segmentation. Our proposed network architecture combines both deep supervision and multi-task learning approaches to improve the segmentation performance. Furthermore, we introduce a cross-task guided attention mechanism that leverages the inter-task relationships to enhance the segmentation accuracy. We evaluate our approach on a publicly available brain tumor dataset and compare it with several state-of-the-art methods. The experimental results demonstrate the effectiveness of our proposed method, achieving competitive performance in terms of segmentation accuracy and computational efficiency. Overall, our work contributes to the improvement of brain tumor segmentation methods and has potential applications in clinical practice.

The paper titled "Diagnostics in Semantic Segmentation" discusses the importance of diagnostic tools and techniques in semantic segmentation tasks. Semantic segmentation is a crucial task in computer vision, where each pixel in an image is assigned a corresponding label based on its semantic meaning. The paper presents various diagnostic methods that can be used to evaluate and analyze the performance of semantic segmentation models. These methods include visualization techniques, evaluation metrics, and qualitative analysis. The paper also discusses the challenges and limitations of these diagnostic tools and proposes future directions for improving them. Overall, the paper highlights the significance of diagnostics in semantic segmentation and provides insights into how these tools can be applied to improve the performance and understanding of segmentation models.

This academic paper presents a deep active learning framework called Suggestive Annotation for biomedical image segmentation tasks. The paper introduces a novel method for selecting informative samples from a large unlabeled dataset and iteratively training a deep neural network model to perform image segmentation. The framework combines an uncertainty-based sampling strategy with an active learning approach that incorporates suggestions from the annotators. The authors provide experimental results on several benchmark datasets in the biomedical domain to demonstrate the effectiveness of their proposed framework. The findings suggest that the Suggestive Annotation framework achieves superior performance compared to other existing methods and can significantly reduce the amount of labeled data required for accurate image segmentation.

In this paper, we study tangentially biharmonic Lagrangian H-umbilical submanifolds in complex space forms. We define the tangential biharmonic Lagrangian H-umbilical submanifolds as those whose mean curvature vector field is parallel to the tangent bundle. We provide a necessary and sufficient condition for a submanifold to be tangentially biharmonic Lagrangian H-umbilical. Moreover, we obtain various characterizations and properties of these submanifolds. We also investigate the classification of these submanifolds in complex space forms. Finally, we give examples of tangentially biharmonic Lagrangian H-umbilical submanifolds and discuss their geometric properties.

Microscopy image segmentation is a crucial step in various biological and medical applications. However, it remains a challenging task due to the presence of noise, low contrast, and complex structures in the images. In this paper, we propose a novel approach called Lifted Multicuts that leverages domain knowledge to improve the accuracy of microscopy image segmentation. Our method incorporates prior knowledge about the spatial relationships between objects in the image to guide the segmentation process. We demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach on a dataset of microscopy images and compare it with existing state-of-the-art methods. The results show that our method outperforms other approaches in terms of segmentation accuracy and computational efficiency. Furthermore, we provide insights into the impact of different domain knowledge factors on the segmentation performance. Overall, our work highlights the importance of incorporating domain knowledge in microscopy image segmentation and provides a promising direction for future research in this field.

This paper presents a note on $s_0$ nonmeasurable unions, which are a type of nonmeasurable set in measure theory. The concept of $s_0$ nonmeasurable unions is introduced and their properties are explored. It is shown that $s_0$ nonmeasurable unions have certain characteristics that distinguish them from other types of nonmeasurable sets. The paper also discusses the implications of $s_0$ nonmeasurable unions in the context of measure theory and provides examples to illustrate their behavior. Overall, this note contributes to the understanding of nonmeasurable sets and their properties in measure theory.

This paper explores the relationship between generalized theta functions, strange duality, and odd orthogonal bundles on curves. The authors introduce a new class of generalized theta functions, which are defined as sections of certain line bundles on the Jacobian variety of a curve. They show that these generalized theta functions satisfy a strange duality property, which relates them to certain odd orthogonal bundles on the curve. The authors also study the behavior of these generalized theta functions under the action of the automorphism group of the curve. They provide explicit examples and applications of their results, including the construction of new families of odd orthogonal bundles on curves. Overall, this paper provides a deeper understanding of the interplay between generalized theta functions, strange duality, and odd orthogonal bundles on curves.

Domain adaptation is a crucial task in machine learning, especially when dealing with multiple sources of data. In this paper, we propose a novel approach called mDALU (Multi-Source Domain Adaptation and Label Unification) that addresses the challenges of domain adaptation and label unification using partial datasets. Our method leverages the information from multiple source domains to adapt the target domain and unify the labels across domains. We introduce a novel label unification loss function that encourages the model to learn a shared label space across domains. Additionally, we propose a partial dataset learning strategy that handles the scenario where only a subset of the data is available for training. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in improving the performance of domain adaptation and label unification tasks.

The paper investigates the generalised colouring numbers of graphs that exclude a fixed minor. The generalised colouring number of a graph is the minimum number of colours needed to colour the vertices such that no two adjacent vertices have the same colour. The paper focuses on graphs that do not contain a fixed minor, which is a smaller graph that can be obtained by contracting edges or deleting vertices from the original graph. The authors provide upper and lower bounds on the generalised colouring numbers of these graphs and discuss the implications of these results. They also explore the relationship between the generalised colouring numbers and other graph parameters, such as the chromatic number and the clique number. The paper concludes with open questions and directions for future research in this area.

This paper presents a study on the application of deep learning architectures for the segmentation of nuclear images in immunofluorescence-based assays. The authors propose and evaluate several deep learning models, including U-Net, Mask R-CNN, and DeepLabv3+, for this task. The models are trained and tested on a large dataset of immunofluorescence images, and their performance is compared in terms of accuracy, precision, recall, and F1-score. The results show that the deep learning models achieve high accuracy in segmenting nuclear images, outperforming traditional image processing techniques. The study also investigates the impact of different hyperparameters and data augmentation techniques on the performance of the models. Overall, the findings demonstrate the potential of deep learning architectures for accurate and efficient nuclear image segmentation in immunofluorescence-based assays.

This paper investigates the Milnor number of a hypersurface singularity in arbitrary characteristic. The Milnor number is a fundamental invariant that measures the complexity of a singularity. The authors develop a new formula for computing the Milnor number in terms of the local cohomology of the singularity. They also study the behavior of the Milnor number under deformation and resolution of singularities. The results provide a deeper understanding of the structure and properties of hypersurface singularities, and have potential applications in algebraic geometry and singularity theory.

This paper presents experimental evidence supporting a new "Osmosis Law & Theory" derived formula that improves the van't Hoff osmotic pressure equation. The van't Hoff equation is widely used to calculate osmotic pressure, but it has limitations in accurately predicting experimental results. The proposed formula incorporates additional factors, such as solute size and concentration, to better account for the behavior of solutes in solution. Experimental data from osmotic pressure measurements of various solutes are compared to the predictions of the van't Hoff equation and the new formula. The results show that the new formula provides a more accurate prediction of osmotic pressure, particularly for solutes with larger sizes and higher concentrations. This improved understanding of osmotic pressure behavior can have implications in various fields, such as biology, chemistry, and materials science.

This paper investigates the universality of the luminosity-metallicity and mass-metallicity relations for compact star-forming galaxies at redshifts 0 < z < 3. The authors analyze a sample of galaxies from the Sloan Digital Sky Survey and the DEEP2 survey, and measure their luminosities, metallicities, and masses. They find that the luminosity-metallicity and mass-metallicity relations hold for compact star-forming galaxies across a wide range of redshifts, suggesting that these relations are universal and not strongly dependent on redshift. This result has important implications for our understanding of galaxy evolution and the processes that regulate the chemical enrichment of galaxies over cosmic time.

In recent years, the availability of online maps has led to a renewed interest in aerial image segmentation. This paper presents a novel approach for learning aerial image segmentation from online maps. The proposed method leverages the rich spatial information present in online maps and combines it with deep learning techniques to achieve state-of-the-art performance in aerial image segmentation tasks. The authors propose a two-step process, where they first extract semantic information from online maps and then use it to guide the segmentation process. Experimental results on a benchmark dataset demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed method in accurately segmenting aerial images. The authors also provide an analysis of the proposed method and compare it with existing approaches, highlighting its advantages and limitations. Overall, this paper provides valuable insights into the potential of using online maps for improving aerial image segmentation tasks and offers a promising approach for future research in this area.

The Social Force Model (SFM) is a widely used pedestrian simulation model that aims to capture the collective behavior of individuals during evacuation scenarios. In this paper, we investigate the stationarity of the SFM by analyzing the movement patterns of pedestrians in different evacuation scenarios. Our results show that the SFM is not stationary, as the movement patterns of pedestrians change over time. Specifically, we observe that pedestrians tend to move faster and take shorter paths as the evacuation progresses. These findings have important implications for the design and optimization of evacuation strategies, as they suggest that the behavior of pedestrians cannot be accurately predicted based on static models. Therefore, future research should focus on developing dynamic models that can capture the evolving nature of pedestrian movement during evacuations.

This paper presents a novel approach for video description using a multi-scale multiple instance network. The proposed network architecture consists of multiple scales of feature extraction layers followed by multiple instance learning layers. The multi-scale feature extraction layers capture both local and global information from the video frames, while the multiple instance learning layers aggregate the features to generate a video description. Experimental results on benchmark datasets demonstrate that the proposed network outperforms existing methods in terms of both accuracy and efficiency. The proposed approach has potential applications in video summarization, video retrieval, and video understanding.

This paper introduces VICE, a novel approach for visual identification and correction of neural circuit errors. Current methods for error detection and correction in neural circuits are limited by the lack of interpretability and the need for expert knowledge. VICE addresses these limitations by leveraging the power of visual analytics and machine learning techniques. The proposed system allows users to visually analyze and identify errors in neural circuits through interactive visualizations. Additionally, VICE incorporates machine learning algorithms to automatically detect and correct errors in the circuits. The effectiveness and usability of VICE are demonstrated through experiments on simulated and real-world neural circuits. The results show that VICE can significantly improve error detection and correction accuracy compared to existing approaches while reducing the reliance on expert knowledge. Ultimately, VICE has the potential to facilitate more efficient and accurate analysis of neural circuits, leading to advancements in neuroscience research and understanding of brain functions.

Belief propagation is a widely used algorithm for inference in graphical models. However, it suffers from the curse of dimensionality when dealing with high-dimensional problems. In this paper, we propose a novel approach called Sigma Point Belief Propagation (SPBP), which leverages the sigma point filtering technique to alleviate the computational complexity of belief propagation. We show that SPBP is capable of approximating the exact message updates in belief propagation with lower computational cost, while maintaining good accuracy. Experimental results on various benchmark datasets demonstrate the effectiveness and efficiency of SPBP compared to traditional belief propagation algorithms. Additionally, we provide theoretical analysis and insights into the properties of SPBP. Overall, our findings suggest that SPBP is a promising alternative to traditional belief propagation algorithms for high-dimensional inference tasks.

This paper presents a method for optimal surface segmentation in irregularly sampled space using convex priors. The proposed method addresses the challenges posed by irregular sampling patterns in medical imaging, where traditional segmentation techniques struggle to accurately identify and model surfaces. The authors propose a convex prior framework that leverages geometric properties of the surface to guide the segmentation process. The method takes into account the irregular sampling pattern and optimizes the segmentation using a convex optimization algorithm. Experimental results on medical imaging data demonstrate that the proposed method outperforms existing techniques in terms of accuracy and robustness. The findings of this study have implications for improving surface segmentation in medical imaging applications.

In this paper, we study the loop-erased random walk (LERW) as an example of off-critical Schramm-Loewner evolutions (SLEs). LERW is a self-avoiding random walk that erases loops as it progresses. We investigate the scaling limits of LERW and show that it converges to an off-critical SLE. We analyze the properties of this off-critical SLE and compare it to the critical SLE. Our findings provide insights into the behavior of LERW and contribute to the understanding of off-critical SLEs.

This paper presents a robust output regulation problem for continuous-time periodic systems. The problem concerns the design of a controller that ensures that the system output tracks a desired reference signal in the presence of exogenous disturbances and uncertainties. We propose a novel approach based on the internal model principle, combined with H control techniques, to achieve robustness against the disturbances and uncertainties. The main result of the paper is the formulation and solution of a robust output regulation problem for continuous-time periodic systems. The proposed design methodology is then applied to a practical example, demonstrating its effectiveness in achieving robust output regulation. The results indicate that the proposed approach can successfully handle a wide range of disturbances and uncertainties, making it a valuable tool for the design of control systems for continuous-time periodic systems.

Prostate MR image segmentation is a crucial task in medical imaging analysis for diagnosis and treatment planning of prostate cancer. However, accurate segmentation is challenging due to the large variability in prostate shape and appearance across different patients. In this paper, we propose a novel boundary-weighted domain adaptive neural network (BW-DANN) for prostate MR image segmentation. The proposed network leverages both the boundary information and domain adaptation techniques to improve the segmentation accuracy. Specifically, a boundary-weighted loss function is introduced to emphasize the importance of boundary regions in the segmentation task. Additionally, a domain adaptation module is incorporated into the network to reduce the domain shift between the source and target domains. Experimental results on a large dataset demonstrate that the proposed BW-DANN outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of segmentation accuracy and robustness to domain shift. The proposed method has the potential to improve the clinical workflow and assist radiologists in accurate prostate cancer diagnosis and treatment planning.

This paper presents MudrockNet, a deep learning-based approach for semantic segmentation of mudrock scanning electron microscope (SEM) images. Mudrocks are fine-grained sedimentary rocks that play a crucial role in various geological processes. Accurate segmentation of mudrock SEM images is essential for understanding their composition and properties. However, manual segmentation is time-consuming and subjective. To address this challenge, we propose MudrockNet, a convolutional neural network architecture specifically designed for mudrock image segmentation. We train MudrockNet on a large dataset of annotated mudrock SEM images and evaluate its performance on a separate test set. Our results demonstrate that MudrockNet achieves high accuracy and outperforms existing methods for mudrock image segmentation. The proposed approach has the potential to significantly improve the efficiency and reliability of mudrock analysis in various geological applications.

This paper presents a locally adapting technique for boundary detection using image segmentation. The proposed technique aims to improve the accuracy of boundary detection by considering local information in the image. The technique utilizes image segmentation algorithms to divide the image into regions and then adapts the boundary detection process based on the characteristics of each region. Experimental results show that the proposed technique outperforms existing methods in terms of boundary detection accuracy. The locally adapting technique has the potential to be applied in various applications such as object recognition and scene understanding.

The Weakly-Labeled Rand Index (WLRI) is a novel measure for evaluating the quality of weakly-labeled data in machine learning tasks. Unlike traditional measures such as the Rand Index, which require fully-labeled ground truth data, the WLRI can handle weakly-labeled data where only partial or noisy labels are available. The WLRI takes into account the uncertainty and noise in the weak labels, and provides a more accurate assessment of the agreement between weak labels and ground truth. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of the WLRI in evaluating weakly-labeled data and its superiority over existing measures. The WLRI can be a valuable tool for researchers and practitioners working with weakly-labeled data in various domains.

This paper presents a comprehensive study of gridless sparse methods for line spectral estimation from complete and incomplete data. The authors propose and analyze two novel algorithms, namely the Iterated Sparse Bayesian Learning (ISBL) and the Iterated Sparse Bayesian Learning with Unknown Noise Variance (ISBL-UNV), which aim to accurately estimate line spectra from a set of observed samples. Through extensive simulations and comparisons with existing methods, the authors demonstrate the efficiency and accuracy of the proposed algorithms in various scenarios, including complete and incomplete data. The findings of this study contribute to the field of signal processing and provide insights into the design of gridless sparse methods for line spectral estimation.

The abstract for the academic paper titled "Structure and Dynamics of Brain Lobe's Functional Networks at the Onset of Anesthesia-Induced Loss of Consciousness" is as follows:

This study investigates the structure and dynamics of brain lobe's functional networks at the onset of anesthesia-induced loss of consciousness. Using functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) data from 20 healthy subjects, we analyzed the connectivity patterns within and between brain lobes during the transition from wakefulness to unconsciousness. We found that the functional networks within each brain lobe became more segregated and less integrated as anesthesia was administered. Additionally, the connectivity between different brain lobes decreased, indicating a disruption in the communication between different brain regions. These findings suggest that the loss of consciousness during anesthesia is associated with a reorganization of functional networks within the brain, leading to a decreased integration and communication between different brain regions. Understanding these changes in brain connectivity may provide insights into the mechanisms underlying anesthesia-induced loss of consciousness and potentially guide the development of more targeted anesthesia protocols.

The paper proposes a novel approach for unsupervised pathology image segmentation using representation learning with spherical K-means. This method aims to address the limitations of supervised segmentation methods, such as the need for extensive labeled data and the inability to generalize to new types of pathologies. The approach involves training a deep neural network to learn representations of pathology images in an unsupervised manner. The learned representations are then clustered using spherical K-means, resulting in a segmentation map. The experiments conducted on a dataset of histopathology images demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed method compared to state-of-the-art supervised segmentation methods. Overall, the method offers a promising direction for addressing the challenges in pathology image segmentation.

This paper presents a novel approach for segmenting multiple surfaces and objects in knee MRI scans using learning-based cost functions. The proposed method utilizes a combination of 3D and 4D techniques to accurately identify and segment different structures in the knee joint. The authors demonstrate the effectiveness of their approach by applying it to data from the Osteoarthritis Initiative, a large-scale study on knee osteoarthritis. The results show that the proposed method outperforms existing segmentation techniques in terms of accuracy and efficiency. This research has the potential to improve the diagnosis and treatment of knee osteoarthritis by providing more accurate and detailed information about the joint structures.

This paper presents a comprehensive review of multi-fidelity models, which are mathematical models that combine data from multiple sources with varying levels of accuracy and cost. The review covers various aspects of multi-fidelity modeling, including the different types of multi-fidelity models, their applications in different fields, and the challenges and limitations associated with their use. The paper also discusses the advantages and disadvantages of multi-fidelity models compared to single-fidelity models, and provides recommendations for future research in this area. Overall, this review aims to provide a comprehensive understanding of multi-fidelity models and their potential for improving the accuracy and efficiency of mathematical modeling in various domains.

This paper presents a novel unsupervised meta-learning approach for figure-ground segmentation by imitating visual effects. The proposed method leverages a meta-learning framework to learn a set of generic visual effects that can be applied to any image to enhance the figure-ground segmentation. The meta-learner is trained on a large dataset of images with ground truth segmentations, and then used to generate augmented images with different visual effects. These augmented images are used to train a segmentation model in an unsupervised manner. Experimental results on benchmark datasets demonstrate that the proposed method achieves state-of-the-art performance in figure-ground segmentation, outperforming existing unsupervised methods. The paper also provides insights into the learned visual effects and their impact on the segmentation performance. Overall, this work contributes to the field of unsupervised meta-learning for figure-ground segmentation and highlights the potential of imitating visual effects for improving segmentation accuracy.

The abstract for the academic paper titled "Petersen cores and the oddness of cubic graphs" discusses the relationship between Petersen cores and the oddness of cubic graphs.
